founder as Indie hackers we often start

things couple customers couple projects
right but what happens when success hits
at some point and your modest database
transforms into this data Behemoth let
me share my experience scaling potan
from the simple database of a couple
items to a system handling Mill millions
of podcasts dozens of millions of
episodes and over a million new tracking
rows daily when you dealing with a few
hundred thousand rows and maybe 50
tables in your database Max life is good
databases remain manageable cres run
smoothly and everything feels under
control it's easy to build against that
but success brings scale hopefully and
scale brings a lot of challenges in
Pan's case it wasn't just about storing
podcast data and metadata we're talking
about millions of podcasts and their
episodes and transcripts and tracking
charts and topic analysis there's a lot
of stuff what started as a
straightforward database with a couple
relationships quickly evolved into this
intricate web of Highly interconnected
data that needed to be instantly
accessible the real challenge here isn't
just a technical side it's juggling both
database architecture and maintenance
while also wearing all these other head
as a solo founder I need to take care of
marketing I need to build product so
when you're handling Marketing sales
customer support and product development
the last thing you want is your database
becoming a full-time job it just can't
happen otherwise your business is going
to fail yet that's exactly what can
happen if you don't plan ahead the first
reality check for me building databases
for pod scan came when simple queres
like give me the latest item in this
table started taking minutes and
sometimes hours and that was bad that's
when I learned the critical importance
of database indices and I knew about
this stuff and I usually put them in but
there are sometimes surprises in there
so for any database at scale an index on
the relevant data is non-negotiable
that's your kind of fast access Lifeline
to frequently create data like creation
dates or podcast IDs in my case that
needs to have an index but here's the
catch while setting up indices during
table creation is pretty painless and
just part of like building a schema
adding them to existing tables with
millions of rows now that's a different
Beast entirely combined indices are even
worse when there's like several items
right when you have your your ID you
created it and some other thing and you
combine them into an index because you
have a query that needs these three
things wow to set that up often requires
a full table scan and that can freeze
your production system for extended
periods let's just call that could be
seconds could be minutes could be hours
and you certainly don't want that and
adding columns usually is a quick thing
but if you have default values that's a
similar challenge because you're
essentially rewriting millions of rows
in a database if you put a default into
every single row and you have millions
already I learned to Less in the hard
way when trying to add a new index to
track podcast episode publishing
patterns what I thought would be a quick
database update and thankfully I tested
locally where it was already fairly slow
and I just had a couple tens of
thousands of items in the database well
it turned into a potential like 20 so
minute downtime situation and that was
completely unacceptable for a service
providing API access to customers who
rely on this so I had to find the way
out and initially I resigned myself to
schedule downtime for maintenance that
was before I had API customers but as
podan grew and started offering an API
downtime became unacceptable you can't
have an API with opening hours I mean
the European Union used to have that for
their value added Text data but that's
not the point like any SAS business has
an API that needs to be there all the
time if they want to offer it as part of
the service so at that point I
discovered AWS rds's blue green
deployments that's a game Cher for
database maintenance so in case you
didn't infer this I run my database on
AWS and I use their database hosted
managed service RDS to keep this mySQL
database running all the time and keep
it upgraded keep it updated keep it
backed up and I'll get to these things
but that's where I run all my data and
for each database in the system AWS
offers these blue green deployments
which is something I didn't know until a
couple months ago when I had to figure
it out and the concept is brilliant you
create a copy of your existing database
and add it as a follower to your
original one and you then have two
synchronized databases on the new
database you perform your time intensive
operations and this is the Green version
that's what they call it the blue is the
original that keeps serving requests in
the background and update the green one
and then you switch over when you're
ready and awsrds handles this elegantly
through dns-based switching which is
really really cool that results in
minimal disruptions because in a way you
don't even have to change your
configuration to change your database
they just switch it internally right
there two servers and they flip a switch
and then the old server gets a new IP
and the new server gets the old IP and
all of a sudden your connection just has
a little hiccup for a second or two and
then things start working again with pod
scan currently being hit by 10 to 20
requests per second from all the
internal and external API requests I
typically see fewer than 25 to 50 errors
during switch over which is not that
much like it's really really fast for
something that I don't even have to
redeploy it's really cool it's a
testament to its reliability I've done
this many times so far and has worked
every single time very quickly so
there's something else I found during
all of these operations if there's
something particularly challenging you
can use a toolkit by the company called
procona they have a really really cool
SQL and just database based toolkit they
have a thing called pt- online D schema
Das change which is a tool that saved me
countless hours a couple months ago
which allows structural change changes
without blocking reads and rights and
without having to redo the whole thing
in the existing table so it creates a
copy of a table that's the idea it
modifies the not the data just the
structure of that table and then it
modifies that structure to I don't know
add an index or add a particular New
Field right that you want with the
default then it synchronously copies
data from the old one to the new table
while maintaining operations on the old
table in the background it's
the same thing as a blue green
deployment but it's inside an existing
database and this approach has been
particularly useful for the creation of
a full text index cuz Man full text
indices adding one to an existing table
with millions of rows that can take
weeks like I tried it it was impossible
to add it particularly because I have so

the name of the episode or maybe a

but I have the full transcript like

items and now imagine a million 2

these rows and trying to create a full

word man no that that took way too long
so PT online schema change that really
helped me do this at that point even on

thing I created a blue green deployment
and then inside the green deployment I
used this tool to make it possible

lean logic was simple here if an episode

it doesn't really make sense however I

but here's the reason why by default
awsrds if you use a mySQL database in
there keeps each table in one file you
can do it so that it keeps every row in

have Shrunk the database size but if

to the file and Mark Parts as deleted
and those parts will still contribute to
the size of the file the only way to do

optimize table on my podcast episode
table and this operation took over 3
days to complete it was crazy long and
day two I was thinking should I stop
this this just ever going to end but I
was committed to seeing it through but
it successfully compressed the storage
needs by 3 terabytes from five down to

monthly AWS bill I have to pay so of
course this means paying for double the

this period of optimiz ization but the

you could not block a table for a copy

that's my personal perspective of course

what it's supposed to use my sql's query
Optimizer is generally quite reliable
you you can send a query and it tries to

in milliseconds using the index that is
something that you really have to be on

like an application performance
monitoring system that shows you which

Sentry and not shy away from using index

that's important like if you building an

after the fact because you see H this
might need it and this might need a
